description: From Middle English faynt, feynt (“weak; feeble”), from Old French faint, feint (“feigned; negligent; sluggish”), past participle of feindre, faindre (“to feign; sham; work negligently”), from Latin fingere (“to touch, handle, form, shape, frame, form in thought, imagine, conceive, contrive, devise, feign”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeyǵʰ- (“to mold”). Cognate with feign and fiction and more distantly dough.

entries.meaning: (of a being) Lacking strength; weak; languid; inclined to lose consciousness
examples: I felt faint after my fifth gin and tonic.

entries.meaning: Lacking courage, spirit, or energy; cowardly; dejected
examples: Faint heart ne'er won fair lady.

entries.meaning: Barely perceptible; not bright, or loud, or sharp
examples: There was a faint red light in the distance.

entries.meaning: Performed, done, or acted, weakly; not exhibiting vigor, strength, or energy

examples: do you have the faintest understanding of what they mean?

entries.meaning: (archaic) Sickly, so as to make a person feel faint.
(rare) The state of one who has fainted; a swoon.

description: From Middle English fainten, feynten, from the adjective (see above).

verbs.description: faint (third-person singular simple present faints, present participle fainting, simple past and past participle fainted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lose consciousness through a lack of oxygen or nutrients to the brain, usually as a result of suddenly reduced blood flow (may be caused by emotional trauma, loss of blood or various medical conditions).
examples: If I send them away fasting  […]  they will faint by the way.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lose courage or spirit; to become depressed or despondent.
(intransitive) To decay; to disappear; to vanish.
examples: Gilded clouds, while we gaze upon them, faint before the eye.
